skill.name: ai-native-development
skill.description: Build AI-first applications with RAG pipelines, embeddings, vector databases, agentic workflows, and LLM integration. Master prompt engineering, function calling, streaming responses, and cost optimization for 2025+ AI development.
skill.summary: Build AI-first applications with RAG pipelines, embeddings, vector databases, agentic workflows, and...
skill.author: AI Agent Hub

security_audit.summary: This skill is educational/reference content for AI-native development patterns. Static scanner flagged 401 patterns, but all are FALSE POSITIVES. The flagged patterns (eval, process.env, backticks, grep commands) are legitimate documentation and template code for building AI agents. No malicious intent, data exfiltration, or unauthorized credential access found.

content.value_statement: Building AI-native applications requires understanding RAG pipelines, agentic workflows, and vector databases. This skill provides proven patterns for integrating LLMs, implementing semantic search, and creating autonomous agents that reason and take action.
actual_capabilities: Implement RAG pipelines with citations and hybrid search
Build autonomous agents using ReAct and function calling patterns
Configure vector databases for semantic search and embeddings
Optimize AI costs through caching and model selection
Set up observability for LLM applications with LangSmith and LangFuse
limitations: Does not include pre-built vector database infrastructure
Does not provide API keys or LLM credentials
Requires separate setup for production deployment

use_cases.title: Build RAG Chatbots
use_cases.description: Create intelligent chatbots that retrieve relevant context from your documents before generating responses.

use_cases.title: Design Agent Systems
use_cases.description: Build multi-agent systems where specialized agents collaborate on complex reasoning tasks.

use_cases.title: Add Semantic Search
use_cases.description: Implement semantic search capabilities that understand meaning beyond keyword matching.

prompt_templates.title: Basic RAG Query
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the RAG pipeline to answer this question based on our knowledge base. Include citations for each claim.

prompt_templates.title: Agent Task
prompt_templates.prompt: Complete this task by reasoning step by step. Use available tools to gather information as needed.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Agent
prompt_templates.prompt: Coordinate these three agents: researcher, analyst, and communicator to complete this complex task.

prompt_templates.title: Cost-Optimized
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze this request and use the appropriate model tier. For simple questions use the faster model.

output_examples.input: How does our return policy work?
output: Retrieved 3 relevant documents from knowledge base

output_examples.input: Research the latest AI regulations and summarize key points
output: Created summary with 5 key regulatory points

output_examples.input: Find similar products to this description
output: Converted product description to embedding vector
Queried vector database for similar items
Sorted by relevance score, top match: 94% similarity

best_practices: Keep context windows under 75% of model limits and implement sliding windows for long conversations
Use hybrid search combining semantic and keyword matching for better retrieval quality
Validate LLM outputs against retrieved context to reduce hallucinations and improve accuracy
anti_patterns: Including sensitive information or secrets in prompts sent to external LLMs
Using a single monolithic prompt for complex tasks instead of decomposing into agent steps
Ignoring token usage and costs without monitoring or budget controls

faq.question: What is the difference between RAG and fine-tuning?
faq.answer: RAG retrieves relevant documents at query time while fine-tuning updates model weights. RAG is cheaper and allows real-time knowledge updates.

faq.question: Which vector database should I choose?
faq.answer: Pinecone offers managed simplicity, Chroma is great for self-hosted, Qdrant provides high performance in Rust. Choose based on your infrastructure.

faq.question: How do I prevent agents from running too long?
faq.answer: Set max_iterations limits, implement timeouts, and add budget controls. Monitor iteration counts and cost per task.

faq.question: What is the ReAct pattern?
faq.answer: ReAct combines Reasoning and Acting. Agents think aloud, take actions, observe results, and iterate until reaching conclusions.

faq.question: How do I handle tool security?
faq.answer: Validate all tool inputs, implement rate limits, use separate credentials per tool, and log all tool executions for audit.

faq.question: When should I use streaming responses?
faq.answer: Use streaming for any user-facing interaction. It reduces perceived latency and improves user experience significantly.
